It is issued for the personal use of*^^V^r^fV?t^^MOST SECRET.Copy No.-W.P. (43) 357.3rd August, 1943.WAR CABINET.ITALYINSTRUMENTS OF SURRENDER.Note by the Prime Minister and Minister of Defence.1. I circulate the attached telegrams and prints of the various instruments of Surrender which we have prepared in case of an approach being made to us by Italy.2. I may say that I deprecate the undue use by us of the expression " united nations." It is necessary sometimes, but in this case it is not right to speak of the United Nations as only Britain and the United States are conducting theaffair and are being consulted. Canada (which has troops engaged) and Russiaare being kept specially informed. We could not tolerate the inclusion of all theUnited Nations in these discussions, which are difficult enough even whenconfined to the two English-speaking countries.3. The United States have usually liked the expression " United Nations,"but we must be careful that Great Britain does not get entirely shut out and that everything that is published does not become either " United States""and general eisenhower'or " United Nations." It must not be forgotten that we are the major,contributors in numbers, - blood, force, ships and aircraft-in-action to this jointenterprise. In this case I understand the United States themselves, and certainlyCanada, have questioned the lavish use of the expression " United Nations." TheDepartments should revise the document from this point of view and see that the term is only used sparingly.w. s. c.10 Botoning Street, S.W. 1,3rd August, 1943.[25856a]

My two immediately succeeding telegrams contain texts of : A. Full Instrument of Surrender for signature by both Italian Governmentand Italian Supreme Command. (Document A.)B. Military Instrument of Surrender for signature by Italian supreme command only. (Document B.)2. Text of Proclamation (Document C) which would be required to supplement Document B is contained in Foreign Office telegram to WashingtonNo. 5008.3. Draft Proclamation (Document D) for use if there is no agreement with either Italian Government or Italian Supreme Command is not yet completebut will be telegraphed as soon as possible.4. We suggest these documents should hereafter be referred as documents a, B, C, or D, as above. Any further amendments which are unlikely to be substantial will be telegraphed either to you or to the Embassy, and repeated toAlgiers.A.War Cabinet Offices to Joint Staff Mission, Washington.(Telegraphic.)(OZ. 2220.) - 2%th July, 1943.MY immediately preceding telegram.Following is text of Draft Instrument of Surrender for acceptance by boththe Italian Government and the Italian Supreme Command : " Whereas the Italian Government and the Italian Supreme Commandacknowledges that the Italian forces have been totally defeated and that Italycan no longer carry on the war against the United Nations and have accordinglyrequested a suspension of hostilities;And whereas the United Nations are willing to lay down the terms on whichthey are prepared to suspend hostilities against Italy provided that their militaryoperations against Germany and her allies are not obstructed, and that Italydoes not assist these Powers in any way :The following terms have been presented by ,on behalf of the Supreme Command of the United Nations, duly authorised -tothat effect, and have been accepted by * ,representing the Supreme Command of the Italian land, sea and air forces, andduly authorised to that effect by the Italian Government: 1. Italian participation in the war in all theatres will cease immediately.There shall be no opposition to landings or other operations of the sea, land andair forces of the United Nations.2. The Italian Supreme Command will give full information concerningthe disposition and condition of all Italian land, sea and air forces, wherever they are situated, and of all such forces of Italy's allies as are situated in Italianor Italian-occupied territory.3. Italian land, sea and air forces will proceed to and remain in theirbarracks, camps or ships, pending directions from the United Nations as to their[25856] - b future status and disposal. Exceptionally, such naval personnel shall proceed toshore establishments as the United Nations may direct.4. Italian land, sea and air forces will, within the periods to be laid downby the United Nations, withdraw from all areas outside Italian territory notified to the Italian Government by the United Nations and proceed to areas to be specified by the United Nations. Such movement of Italian land, sea and airforces will be carried out in conditions to be laid down by the United nations and in accordance with the orders to be issued by them. All Italian officials willsimilarly leave the areas notified, except any who may be permitted to remainby the United Nations. Those permitted to remain will comply with the instruc-tions of the United Nations.5. No requisitioning, seizures or other coercive measures shall be effected by Italian land, sea and air forces or officials in regard to persons or property in the areas notified under Article 4.8. The demobilisation of Italian land, sea and air forces in excess of suchestablishments as shall be notified will take place as prescribed by the united nations.7. Italian warships of all descriptions, auxiliaries and transports will be assembled as directed in ports to be specified by the United Nations and will bedealt with as prescribed by the United Nations. (Note. If at the date of theArmistice the whole of the Italian fleet has been assembled in Allied ports, thisArticle would run : ' Italian warships of all descriptions, auxiliaries and trans-ports will remain in the ports where they are at present assembled, subject toany instructions which may be issued by the United Nations, and will be dealtwith as prescribed by the United Nations.')8. Italian aircraft of all kinds will not leave the ground or water or ships;except as directed by the United Nations.9. Without prejudice to the provisions of Articles 14, 16 and 29 below,all merchant ships, fishing or other craft of whatever flag, all aircraft and inland transport of whatever nationality in Italian or Italian-occupied territory orwaters will, pending verification of their identity and status, be prevented from leaving.10. The Italian Supreme Command will make available all information about naval, military and air devices, installations, and. defences; about all inter-communication systems established by Italy or her Allies on Italian territory orin the approaches thereto; about minefields or other obstacles to movement byland, sea or air and such other particulars as the United Nations may requirein connection with the use of Italian bases, or with the operations, security, orwelfare of the United Nations land, sea or air forces. Italian forces and equip-ment will be made available as required by the United Nations for the removalof the above-mentioned obstacles.11. The Italian Government will furnish forthwith lists of quantities ofall war material showing the location of the same. The war material will beplaced in store under such control as the United Nations may direct. Theultimate disposal of war material will be prescribed by the United Nations.12. There shall be no destruction of, nor damage to, nor, except asauthorised or directed by the United Nations, any removal of war material,wireless, radiolocation or meteorological stations, rail, road, port or other installa-tions. or in general, public or private utilities or property of any kind, whereversituated; and the necessary maintenance and repair will be the responsibility ofthe Italian authorities.13. The manufacture, production and construction of war material andthe import, export and transit of such war material is prohibited, except asdirected, by the United Nations. The Italian Government will comply with anydirections given by the United Nations for the manufacture, production orconstruction and the import, export or transit of such war material. .14. (a) All Italian merchant shipping and fishing and other craft, wherever they may be, and any constructed, or completed during the period of the presentInstrument will be made available in good repair and in seaworthy condition bythe competent Italian authorities at such places and for such purposes and periodsas the United Nations may prescribe. Transfer to enemy or neutral flags is prohibited. Crews shall remain on board, pending further instructionsregarding their continued employment or disposal. Any existing options torepurchase or reacquire or to resume control of Italian or former Italian vesselssold or otherwise transferred or chartered during the war shall forthwith beexercised, and the above provisions shall apply to all such vessels and their crews.(b) All Italian inland transport shall be held at the disposal of the united nations for such purposes as they may direct.15. The United Nations will endeavour to provide for the essentialeconomic needs of the Italian people so far as circumstances permit; but theyreserve the right to recover the cost of supplies and transport for the purpose fromthe Italian Government. It is to the interest of the Italian Government and people to ensure that Italian ships and equipment are made available in good andserviceable condition, together with their crews as required.16. United Nations merchant ships, fishing, and other craft in Italian handswherever they may be (including for this purpose those of any country which hasbroken off diplomatic relations with Italy, whether or not the title has beentransferred as the result of prize court proceedings or otherwise) will be surrendered to the United Nations and will be assembled in ports to be specified by the United Nations for disposal as directed by them. The Italian Governmentwill take all such steps as.may be required to secure any necessary transfers of title. Any neutral merchant ships, fishing .or other craft under Italian opera-tions or control will be assembled in the same manner pending arrangements fortheir ultimate disposal. Any necessary repairs to any of the above-mentionedvessels will be effected by the Italian Government, if required and at theirexpense.17. No radio or telecommunication installations or other forms of inter-communication, ashore or afloat, under Italian control whether belonging to Italyor any nation other than the United Nations will transmit until directions for thecontrol of these installations have been prescribed by the United Nations. TheUnited Nations will institute such censorship of press broadcasting and publica-tions and supervision of intercommunication as may be necessary, or at theirliscretion, may take over radio, cable and other communication stations.18. The warships, auxiliaries, transports and merchant and other vessels and aircraft in the service of the United Nations will have the right freely touse the territorial waters around and the air over Italian territory.19. The United Nations will require to occupy certain parts of italian territory. The territories or areas concerned will from time to time be notifiedby the United Nations, and all Italian land, sea and air forces will thereuponwithdraw from such territories or areas in accordance with the instructions issued by the United Nations. The provisions of this Article are withoutprejudice to those of Article 4 above.20. In the territories or areas referred to in Article 19 all naval, militaryand air installations, power stations, all ports and harbours, all transport andall intercommunication installations, facilities and equipment and such otherinstallations or facilities as may be required by the United Nations will be madeavailable in good condition by the competent Italian authorities with .the personnel required for working them. The Italian Government will also supply,free of cost, such other local resources or services as the United Nations may require.21. Without prejudice to the provisions of the present Instrument theUnited Nations will exercise all the rights of an occupying Power in the territories or areas referred to in Article 19. Personnel of the Italianadministrative, judicial and public services will carry out their functions underthe control of the United Nations Supreme Command, unless otherwise directed.22. In addition to the rights in respect of occupied Italian territoryprescribed by Articles 19-21,(a) members of the land, sea or air forces and officials of the United nations will have the right of passage in or over non-occupied Italian territory and willbe afforded all the necessary facilities and assistance in performing their functions;(b) the Italian authorities will make available in non-occupied italian territory all transport facilities required by the United Nations, including freetransit for their war material and supplies; and will comply with instructions issued by the United Nations regarding the use and control of airfields, ports,shipping, "inland transport systems and vehicles, intercommunication systems,power-stations and public utility services, and connected repair and constructionfacilities.23. The Italian Government and people will abstain from all action detri-mental to the interests of the United Nations and will carry out promptly and efficiently all orders given by the United Nations.24. The Italian Government will supply free of cost such Italian currencyas the United Nations may require. The Italian Government will withdraw andredeem in Italian currency within such time-limits and on such terms as theUnited Nations may specify all holdings in Italian territory of currencies issuedby the United Nations during military operations or occupation and will hand,over the currencies so withdrawn free of cost to the United Nations. TheItalian Government will take such measures as may be required by the united nations for the control of banks and businesses in Italian territory, for thecontrol of foreign exchange and foreign commercial and financial transactions and for the regulation of trade and production, and will comply with any instructions issued by the United Nations regarding these and similar matters.25. There shall be no financial, commercial or other intercourse with ordealings with or for the benefit of countries at war with any of the United nations or territories occupied by such countries.26. Relations with countries at war with any of the United Nations, or occupied by any such country, will be broken off. Italian diplomatic and consularofficials accredited to or serving on missions with any such country will be recalled. Diplomatic and consular officials of such countries will be dealt withas the United Nations may prescribe.27. Italian subjects will, pending further instructions, be prevented from leaving Italian territory except as authorised by the United Nations, and will not!in any event take service with any of the countries referred to in Article 26, norwill they proceed to any place for the purpose of undertaking work for any suchcountry. Those at present so serving or working will be recalled as directed bythe United Nations.28. The military, naval and air personnel and material and the merchantshipping, fishing and other craft and the aircraft, vehicles and other transportequipment of any country against which any of the United Nations is carryingon hostilities, or which is occupied by any such country, remain liable to attackor seizure wherever found in or over Italian territory or waters.29. The warships, auxiliaries and transports of any such country or occupied country referred to in Article 28 in Italian or Italian-occupied ports andwaters and the aircraft vehicles and other transport equipment of such countriesin or over Italian or Italian-occupied territory will, pending further instructions,be prevented from leaving.(&) The military, naval and air personnel and the civilian nationals of anysuch country or occupied country in Italian or Italian-occupied territory will be prevented from leaving and will be interned pending further instructions.(c) All property in Italian territory belonging to any such country or occupied country or its nationals will be impounded and kept in custody pending further instructions.(d) The Italian Government will comply with any instructions given by theUnited Nations concerning the internment, custody or subsequent disposal,utilisation or employment of any of the above-mentioned persons, vessels, aircraft,material or property.30. All persons suspected of having committed war crimes or analogousoffences whose names appear on lists to be communicated by the United nations will forthwith be apprehended and surrendered into the hands of the united nations. Any instructions given by the United Nations for this purpose willbe complied with.31. All Fascist organisations, including alFbranches of the Fascist militia(M.V.S.N.), the secret police (O.V.R.A.) and Fascist youth organisations will be disbanded in accordance with the directions of the United Nations, except anysuch organisations or parts thereof as may be specified by the United Nations. 32. All Italian laws involving discrimination on grounds of race, religionor political opinions will be rescinded, and persons detained on such grounds will,as directed by the United Nations, be released and relieved from all legaldisabilities to which they have been subjected.- 33. (a) Prisoners of war belonging, to the forces of the United Nations andany nationals of the United Nations, including Abyssinian subjects, confined,interned, or otherwise under restraint in Italian or Italian-occupied territory willnot be removed and will forthwith be handed over to representatives of the united nations or otherwise dealt with as the United Nations may direct.(b) Persons of whatever nationality, including Albanians, who have beenplaced under restriction, detention or sentence (including sentences in absentia)on account of their dealings or sympathies with the United Nations, will be released under the direction of the United Nations, and relieved from all legaldisabilities to which they have been subjected.(c) The Italian Government will take such steps as the United Nations may direct to safeguard the persons and property of foreign States and nationals.34. (a) The Italian Government will comply with such directions as theUnited Nations may prescribe regarding restitution, deliveries or payments byway of reparation and payment of the costs of occupation during the period ofthe present Instrument.(b) The Italian Government will give to the United Nations such informationas may be prescribed regarding the assets, whether inside or outside Italian terri-tory, of the Italian State, the Bank of Italy, any Italian State or semi-State,institutions or Fascist organisations, or residents in Italian territory, and willnot dispose or allow the disposal outside Italian territory of any such assets,except with the permission of the United Nations.35. The Italian Government will carry out during the period of the presentInstrument such measures of disarmament and demilitarisation as may be prescribed by the United Nations.36. The Italian Government. will supply all information and provide alldocuments required by the United Nations.37. The Italian Government will pass and enforce such legislative andadministrative measures as may be necessary for the execution of the presentInstrument. Italian military and civil authorities will comply with any instruc-tions issued by the United Nations for the same purpose.38. The term ' the United Nations ' in the present Instrument includes the Control Commission referred to in Article 42 below, the Supreme Command ofthe United Nations, and any other authority which the United Nations maydesignate for the purpose.39. Reference to Italian land, sea and air forces in the present Instrumentshall be deemed to include Fascist Militia and all such other military or para-military units, formations or bodies as the United Nations may prescribe.40. The term ' war material ' in the present Instrument denotes allmaterial specified in such lists or definitions as may from time to time be issuedby the Control Commission referred to in Article 42 below.41. The term ' Italian territory' includes all Italian colonies anddependencies and shall, for the purposes of the present Instrument (but withoutprejudice to the question of sovereignty) be deemed, to include Albania; providedhowever that, except in such cases and to such extent as the United Nations may direct, the provisions of the present Instrument shall not apply in or affect theadministration of any Italian colony or dependency already occupied by theUnited Nations or the rights or powers therein possessed, or exercised by them.42. A Control Commission appointed by the United Nations will regulateand control the execution of the present Instrument. Any disagreementregarding the interpretation or execution of the present Instrument will bedecided by the Control Commission, whose decision will be final.43. The Italian Government will send a delegation to the headquarters ofthe Control Commission to represent Italian interests and to transmit the orders of the Commission to the competent Italian authorities.44. The present Instrument will be confirmed by the Italian Government.It shall enter into force hours after the Instrument of Confirma-tion has been received at and hostilities between the United Nations and Italy will cease in all theatres of war at that time. It willremain in operation until the coming into force of the Peace Treaty with Italy.45. The present Instrument may be denounced by the United Nations withimmediate effect if the Italian Government do iiot fulfil their obligations underthe Instrument or, as an alternative, the United Nations may penalisecontravention of it by measures appropriate to the circumstances such as theextension of the areas of military occupation, or air or other punitive action.Drawn up in English and Italian, the English text being authentic, andsigned on the at (hour)(time) at (place).(Signatures.) The present Instrument may be denounced by the United Nations with,immediate effect if Italian obligations thereunder are not fulfilled or, as analternative, the United Nations may penalise contravention of it by measures,appropriate to the circumstances, such as the extension of the areas of military occupation, or air or other punitive action.Drawn up in English and Italian, the English text being authentic; andsigned on the at (hour)(time) at (place).(Signatures)"C.Foreign Office to Washington.(No. 5008.)(Telegraphic.) 29th July, 1943.(Repeated to Resident Minister, Algiers, No. 1433.)MY telegram No. 4996 (not reproduced).Following is text of Proclamation referred to in last paragraph : " Whereas the United Nations have, at the request of the Italian supreme command, specified the military terms on which for the time being and pendingany further arrangements they are willing to suspend hostilities against Italyand such terms have been accepted and signed by the Italian Supreme Command;And whereas it is necessary confer the forces of the United Nations to occupyItalian territory for the prosecution of the war against Italy's allies and as aguarantee of the execution of the above-mentioned terms;And whereas it is necessary to make provision for the maintenance of public order in such territory, the safety and sustenance of the Italian people and themilitary security and requirements of the occupying forces;And -whereas there exists no Italian administration with which the united nations are prepared to deal in the matter;Now therefore I [United Nations Commander-in-Chief ] hereby proclaim : 1. All Italian territories now or hereafter occupied by any forces under my command will be under my exclusive military jurisdiction and will remain under such jurisdiction for as long as military considerations demand and until an Italian Government recognised by the United Nations is established. For thispurpose, therefore, I -assume for myself and for any duly appointed successor of mine full judicial, legislative, administrative and executive powers and responsibility in regard to all territories in Italy occupied from time to time bythe forces of the United Nations and exclusive military jurisdiction over allpersons and property therein.2. Subject to such Orders and Regulations as may be prescribed by me,Italian Courts, both penal and civil, shall continue to function with the exceptionof those specified in Article 9 below.3. Proclamations issued by me will make such provision as may be deemed necessary in relation to the administration of martial law. Offences againstProclamations or Orders or Regulations issued thereunder other offencesas I may determine will be tried by military courts. -4. Save as provided in Articles 10 and 11 below or as may be otherwisedirected, all lawfully established local administrative authorities, and all officersand employees of all State, Municipal and other public services are hereby autho-rised and required to continue to execute and discharge their duties, powers and functions, subject to such conditions or limitations as may be prescribed by me.They will be responsible for taking such action as lies within their sphere for safeguarding life and property, preventing sabotage and maintaining order.5. With the exceptions mentioned in Articles 12 and 13 below and save asmay be otherwise directed, the existing laws and regulations (including those relating to the level of prices, the hoarding of foodstuffs or other commodities,and the rationing of provisions, clothing or other commodities) will continue inforce.6. I will take all steps which I may deem necessary and expedient for thepurpose of establishing and maintaining public order and safety and so far aspossible for safeguarding the economic needs of the people, and in so doing I willas far as military exigencies and considerations of public order and safety permit,respect all laws, customs, rights and properties in the occupied territories. All requisitioning of private services and. property which may be necessitated by military exigency will be subject to reasonable compensation as provided for inthe Convention of The Hague concerning the Laws and Customs of War on Land.7. I hereby call upon all persons in Italian territory to preserve order andtranquility, to abstain from any action which might lead to disorder, to go about their normal occupations so far as these are lawful under military occupation,and to conform promptly to all orders given by me or under my authority.8. For reasons of military security and administration, or on grounds ofpublic order and safety, or' for giving, effect to the rights conferred on an army of occupation by the above-mentioned Hague Convention, it is necessary thatcertain measures should be put into immediate effect. The said measures are setout in the Articles now following.9. The Italian Special Tribunal for the Defence of the State and anyregional or subordinate tribunal of the same character is hereby suspended.10. The Fascist Party Organisations and other Fascist Organisationsincluding all branches of the Fascist Militia (M.V.S.N.), the Secret Police(O.V.R.A.) and Fascist Youth Organisations shall, except as otherwise directed by me in any particular case, cease to function. Fascist Leaders and prominentmembers of the Fascist party, whether officials or not, will be interned. Fascistfunds in banks are frozen. Other Fascist funds and funds intended for Fascistpurposes will be taken over for safe custody.11.- Fascist clubs, centres and other Fascist institutions will be closed. the teaching in schools and other institutions of Fascist ideas, Fascist politicaleconomy and any subjects with a Fascist bias, is forbidden. All text books towhich exception is taken will be withdrawn. The display of Fascist flags andemblems over houses and the wearing of Fascist uniforms and emblems are prohibited.12. All Italian laws and regulations involving discrimination on grounds of religion, race, language or political beliefs are suspended, and persons detainedon such grounds will, as directed by me, be released and all legal disabilities towhich they have been subjected will cease to be enforced.13. Persons of whatever nationality, including Albanians, who have beenplaced under restriction, detention or sentence (including sentence in absentia) onaccount of their dealings' or sympathies with the United Nations will be releasedunder direction, and all legal disabilities to which they have been subjected will cease to be enforced.14. Pending further instructions, Italian subjects will not leave italian territory except as authorised by me, and will not in any event take service withany country which is at war with any of the United Nations, or occupied by suchcountry; nor will they proceed to any place for the purpose of undertaking workfor any such country.15. Relations with countries at war with any of the United Nations, or occupied by any such country, will be suspended. Italian diplomatic and consularofficials accredited to or serving on missions with any such country will be recalled. Diplomatic and consular officials of such countries will be dealt withas I may prescribe.16. All financial, commercial or other intercourse with or dealings with orfor the benefit of countries at war with any of the United Nations or territoriesoccupied by such countries shall forthwith cease.17. The export or transfer abroad Of currency, bonds or property is prohibited except in special instances for which my authority will be necessary.All gold held by banks on behalf of the late Italian Government will be disposedof as I may direct.18. All property in Italian territory belonging to any country, against which any of the United Nations is engaged in active hostilities, or which is occupiedby any such country, or belonging to the nationals of such country, will beimpounded and kept in custody pending further instructions. The competentItalian authorities will comply with any instructions concerning the custody orsubsequent disposal of any such property.19. The competent Italian authorities will take all necessary steps including such special steps as I may direct to safeguard' the persons of foreign nationalsand the property of foreign States and nationals.20. No radio or telecommunication installations or other form of inter-communication, ashore or afloat, under Italian control, whether belonging to Italy or any nation other than the United Nations, will transmit until directions forthe control "of these installations have been prescribed by the United Nations.Such measures as I may direct will be instituted for the control and censorshipof postal, telegraphic, telephonic and radio communications, of publications inthe Press, of theatrical and cinematograph performances and of broadcasting.21. Strikes and lock-outs, incitements to strike, and all participation in labour disputes are hereby prohibited.22. The competent Italian authorities will take such measures as may berequired by me for the control of banks and businesses in Italian territory, forthe control of foreign exchange, and foreign commercial and financial trans-actions and for the regulation of trade and production, and will comply with any instructions issued by me regarding these and similar matters.23. The competent Italian authorities will supply free of cost such Italiancurrency as the United Nations may require for military necessities and theadministration of the occupied territories, and will withdraw and redeem in italian currency within such time-limits and on such terms as may be specfiedall holdings in Italian territory of currencies issued by the United Nations duringmilitary operations or occupation, and will hand over the currencies so withdrawnfree of cost to the United Nations.24. All war material will at once be handed over to the local commander ofthe occupying forces on arrival.25. The manufacture, production and construction of war material and theimport, export and transit of such war material is prohibited, except as directed by me. The competent Italian authorities will comply with any directions givenby me for the manufacture, production or construction and the import, export and transit of such war material.26. The Italian authorities will make available all transport facilities as required, and will comply with all instructions issued by me regarding the use and control of airfields, ports, shipping, inland transport systems and vehicles,wireless and" inter-communication systems and appliances, power stations andpublic utility services, and connected repair and construction facilities.27. All persons suspected of having committed war crimes or analogousoffences whose names appear on lists to be issued by me will forthwith be appre-apprehended and surrendered into the hands of the United Nations. The competentItalian authorities will comply with all directions given by me for this purpose.28. The competent Italian authorities will supply all information and provide all documents required by me on any matter dealt with in or arising outof this Proclamation or any subsequent Proclamation^ Order or Regulation.29. The competent Italian authorities, civil and military, the officials and employees of all Government departments and regional authorities will take ailsuch steps as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this Proclamation orof any subsequent Proclamation, Order or Regulation, and will comply with allinstructions given them for that purpose; they will afford all necessary facilities to the occupying forces, their advance guards and agents; and will collaboratefully with the officers of the occupying forces in all measures necessary for thesecurity, communications and supply of these forces.30. The references in this Proclamation or any subsequent Proclamation,Order or Regulation to orders, directions or instructions given by me will bedeemed to include those issued by any duly appointed successor of mine, or by orunder my authority or that of any such successor, or by any deputy or other duly authorised person.31. This Proclamation will operate in the occupied territories as supple-menting the Instrument entered into by the Italian Supreme Command withmyself, and is to be read in conjunction with that Instrument, the terms of whichI hereby call upon authorities, officials and people in these territories to observeso far as they severally are concerned.32. The detailed application of the provisions of this Proclamation willso far as requisite be effected by means of further Proclamations or by Orders or regulations issued under this or any subsequent Proclamation.33.
